content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <feed xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <title>Georgia Tech Library</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/3741" rel="alternate"/> <subtitle>An Intellectual Center for the campus community.</subtitle> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/3741</id> <updated>2015-03-15T23:20:25Z</updated> <dc:date>2015-03-15T23:20:25Z</dc:date> <entry> <title>The DLF Show</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/53215" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Bennett, Charlie</name> </author> <author> <name>Doshi, Ameet</name> </author> <author> <name>Hagenmaier, Wendy</name> </author> <author> <name>Rascoe, Fred</name> </author> <author> <name>Rolando, Lizzy</name> </author> <author> <name>Shreeves, Sarah</name> </author> <author> <name>Vinopal, Jennifer</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/53215</id> <updated>2015-03-12T12:25:30Z</updated> <published>2014-10-17T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">The DLF Show Bennett, Charlie; Doshi, Ameet; Hagenmaier, Wendy; Rascoe, Fred; Rolando, Lizzy; Shreeves, Sarah; Vinopal, Jennifer Podcast version of Oct 17, 2014 broadcast of Lost in the Stacks. Hosted by Ameet Doshi and Charlie Bennett. Featuring an interview with Sarah Shreeves, IDEALS Coordinator, Scholarly Commons Co-coordinator, University of Illinois Libraries, and Jennifer Vinopal, Librarian for Digital Scholarship Initiatives, New York University Library. </summary> <dc:date>2014-10-17T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>Bennett, Charlie</dc:creator> <dc:creator>Doshi, Ameet</dc:creator> <dc:creator>Hagenmaier, Wendy</dc:creator> <dc:creator>Rascoe, Fred</dc:creator> <dc:creator>Rolando, Lizzy</dc:creator> <dc:creator>Shreeves, Sarah</dc:creator> <dc:creator>Vinopal, Jennifer</dc:creator> <dc:description>Podcast version of Oct 17, 2014 broadcast of Lost in the Stacks. Hosted by Ameet Doshi and Charlie Bennett. Featuring an interview with Sarah Shreeves, IDEALS Coordinator, Scholarly Commons Co-coordinator, University of Illinois Libraries, and Jennifer Vinopal, Librarian for Digital Scholarship Initiatives, New York University Library.</dc:description> </entry> <entry> <title>Information Sources and Collection Planning for Engineering</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/53180" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Baer, William</name> </author> <author> <name>Renfro, Crystal</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/53180</id> <updated>2015-02-15T08:30:48Z</updated> <published>2013-01-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Information Sources and Collection Planning for Engineering Baer, William; Renfro, Crystal This chapter will provide background for practicing librarians who have collection development responsibilities for engineering programs at academic institutions. Although it is intended as a resource for all engineering bibliographers, new librarians or those new to the technical fields may find it especially useful. Engineers (and engineering students) use information quite differently than other disciplines, and this can make collection development a daunting task. Furthermore, it is common for librarians with no background in engineering or technology to be assigned to manage the engineering collection. The information and tips contained in this chapter are meant to make this job easier. DOI: 10.4018/978-1-4666-1897-8.ch008 </summary> <dc:date>2013-01-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>Baer, William</dc:creator> <dc:creator>Renfro, Crystal</dc:creator> <dc:description>This chapter will provide background for practicing librarians who have collection development responsibilities for engineering programs at academic institutions. Although it is intended as a resource for all engineering bibliographers, new librarians or those new to the technical fields may find it especially useful. Engineers (and engineering students) use information quite differently than other disciplines, and this can make collection development a daunting task. Furthermore, it is common for librarians with no background in engineering or technology to be assigned to manage the engineering collection. The information and tips contained in this chapter are meant to make this job easier.</dc:description> </entry> <entry> <title>Using Participatory Management in Access Services Improves Staff Quality and Participation in Decision-Making</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/53131" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Morrison, Ray L.</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/53131</id> <updated>2015-01-15T08:35:35Z</updated> <published>2014-11-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Using Participatory Management in Access Services Improves Staff Quality and Participation in Decision-Making Morrison, Ray L. Access Services Librarians are now beginning to use participatory management to successfully direct their staff. Using participatory management increases work productivity, greater job satisfaction, higher level of motivation, improved quality and reduced costs. The speaker is an advocate of participatory management and has used it as a Library Director for over two decades and now as the Coordinator of Access Services. Presented at the 2014 Access Services Conference, November 12-14, 2014, Georgia Tech Global Learning Center and the Georgia Tech Hotel and Conference Center, Atlanta, Georgia. </summary> <dc:date>2014-11-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>Morrison, Ray L.</dc:creator> <dc:description>Access Services Librarians are now beginning to use participatory management to successfully direct their staff. Using participatory management increases work productivity, greater job satisfaction, higher level of motivation, improved quality and reduced costs. The speaker is an advocate of participatory management and has used it as a Library Director for over two decades and now as the Coordinator of Access Services.</dc:description> </entry> <entry> <title>Student Library Use Data and Class Standing</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/53130" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Sneed, Thomas</name> </author> <author> <name>Walsh, Felicity</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/53130</id> <updated>2015-01-15T08:35:33Z</updated> <published>2014-11-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Student Library Use Data and Class Standing Sneed, Thomas; Walsh, Felicity Budgets are tight at academic institutions everywhere and this can affect library budgets.  This year, MacMillan Library had harvested and combined data on student GPAs, library circulation data and gate entrance data to see if there is any correlation between library use and student success. Presented at the 2014 Access Services Conference, November 12-14, 2014, Georgia Tech Global Learning Center and the Georgia Tech Hotel and Conference Center, Atlanta, Georgia. </summary> <dc:date>2014-11-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>Sneed, Thomas</dc:creator> <dc:creator>Walsh, Felicity</dc:creator> <dc:description>Budgets are tight at academic institutions everywhere and this can affect library budgets.  This year, MacMillan Library had harvested and combined data on student GPAs, library circulation data and gate entrance data to see if there is any correlation between library use and student success.</dc:description> </entry> </feed>
